docs.lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it would stop paying for health insurance for members of its board. The agency made the move in response to a legal opinion by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo that determined the practice was improper. The authority said that 4 of its 21 board members were receiving benefits through the New York State Health Insurance Plan. The combined insurance payments for the four would have cost the authority about $40,000 this year, said Jeremy Soffin, a spokesman for the authority. The four board members had been paying what would normally be considered employees’ shares of the premiums, Mr. Soffin said.

byline.original: By WILLIAM NEUMAN; Compiled by John Sullivan

docs.lead_paragraph: Two reports being published today call for greatly expanded use of M.R.I. scans in women who have breast cancer or are at high risk for it. The recommendations do not apply to most healthy women, who have only an average risk of developing the disease.

headline.main: MUCH WIDER USE OF M.R.I.'S URGED FOR BREAST EXAM

docs.abstract: Two new reports recommend greatly expanded use of MRI scans in women who have breast cancer or are at high risk; study in New England Journal of Medicine shows that in women with newly-diagnosed cancer in one breast MRI can find tumors in other breast that mammograms miss; high rate of false-positive results may be acceptable in women likely to have hidden tumors, but risk of needless biopsies and scans is not considered reasonable for others; new American Cancer Society guidelines recommend yearly scans and mammograms starting at age 30 for women who have genetic markers of breast cancer in close relatives; Dr Elizabeth Morris stresses physician's responsibility in determining risk factors, especially if demand for costly scans outstrips capacity; photo; Dr Constance Lehman explains second study on MRI picking up tumors that mammograms missed (M)
docs.snippet: Two reports being published today call for greatly expanded use of M.R.I. scans in women who have breast cancer or are at high risk for it.      The recommendations do not apply to most healthy women, who have only an average risk of developing the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.
docs.abstract: In this lesson, students share words and associations related to cancer. They then investigate and participate in dialogues about the diagnosis and treatment of breast cancer. Learning is synthesized by writing and designing a booklet with talking points for discussing breast cancer with families.

docs.lead_paragraph: TRENTON, March 26 — Carla Katz, a former companion of Gov. Jon S. Corzine’s and the president of a major state employees’ union, responded to a 2005 demand from the federal government that she disclose gifts that Mr. Corzine had made to her with a four-page letter arguing that the gifts were not subject to disclosure requirements.
